unit: Unit 9 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Slopes
title: Height/Arm Span Relationship
question_text:
Scientists wish to determine if there is a positive linear relationship between height and arm span.
Which of the following would give us evidence of a positive relationship between these variables in a sample of $40$ random subjects?

choices.text: The correlation coefficient being close to $-1$.

The p-value in a linear regression $T$-test being close to $0$ when testing
$H_0 : B = 0$
$H_a: B > 0$
A residual plot that shows the data points haphazardly scattered.
A slope in the LSRL close to $1$.
A scatterplot without any influential points or outliers.

solution:
This problem tests the ability to interpret results from linear regression.

A linear regression $T$-test will give evidence of a linear relationship (positive or negative) if the $p$-value is close to $0$.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect; this is a positive relationship, so the correlation coefficient, $r$, will be close to $1$, not $-1$.

Choice 'C' is incorrect; a residual plot with the points haphazardly scattered shows that a linear model is the best fit, but it does not prove that the linear model has a strong positive relationship.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; just because our sample data has a slope of $1$ does not necessarily mean a strong correlation exists.

Choice 'E' is incorrect; while influential points and outliers can weaken a linear model, their lack of presence does not automatically make the model good.
